facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 280 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 280 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 2, 1960 of Rajasthan High Court in D.E. Civil Misc. Election Appeal No. 1 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2, 1960, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. E. Civil Misc.  Election  Appeal, No. 1

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on February 8, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR., J.-This appeal by special leave arises out

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition challenging validity of election of respondent No. 1, Lal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of an election petition filed by the appellant challenging the validity of the election of respondent No. 1, Lal Singh on several grounds.

facts.text: Appellant is an elector in Chittorgarh Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is an elector in the Chittorgarh Constituency and the election which led to the present petition

facts.text: Election held in March 1957 for Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from Chittorgarh Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: was held in March. 1957, for the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from the said companystituency.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1, Lal Singh, declared duly elected on 11th March 1957 with 7272 votes.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the election, respondent No. 1 was declared to have been duly elected on the 11th March, 1957. He secured 7272 votes whereas

facts.text: Respondent No. 2, Laxman Singh s/o Maharawal Sir Bijey Singh, secured 7261 votes.

anchor.surface_text: whereas respondent No. 2 Laxman Singh s o Maharawal Sir Bijey Singh secured 7261 votes and respondent No. 3 Chhoga lal secured 569 votes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3, Chhoga Lal, secured 569 votes.

anchor.surface_text: and respondent No. 3 Chhoga lal secured 569 votes.

facts.text: Appellant alleged respondent No. 1 procured or abetted invalid votes, materially affecting result.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that respondent No. 1s election wag invalid inasmuch as he had practiced companyrupt practices at the said election. According to the appellant, respondent No. 1 procured or abetted

facts.text: Appellant alleged respondent No. 1 and agents published false statements Exts. 3 and 6 about respondent No. 2's personal character or conduct.

anchor.surface_text: or attempted to procure either by himself or by his agents or by other persons with his companynivance or that of his agents the reception of invalid votes and as a result of the said votes, the result of the Election had been materially affected The appellant stated in detail the manner in which the said invalid votes bad been procured. The appellant further pleaded that respondent No. 1, his agents and other persons with the companynivance of respondent No. 1 or that of his agents published such statements of facts  Exts. 3 6  which were false

facts.text: Appellant claimed declaration that respondent No. 2 should be declared validly elected.

anchor.surface_text: It is on these two grounds that the appellant claimed a declaration that the election of respondent No. 1 was invalid. He also claimed that respondent No. 2 should be declared to have been validly elected.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 filed written statement supporting petition but did not appear at hearing.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 filed his written statement supporting the petition but he did number appear before the Tribunal at the hearing.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 did not appear at all.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 did number appear at all, while respondent No. 1 denied all the allegations made by the appellant

facts.text: Election Tribunal held allegations of invalid votes not proved.

anchor.surface_text: On the pleadings of the parties, the Election Tribunal framed as many as 26 issues. In substance it held that the several allegations made by the appellant in respect of the receipt of invalid votes bad number been proved

facts.text: Election Tribunal held Ext. 3 published by agent of respondent No. 1 but not with express consent.

anchor.surface_text: and so the first ground on which respondent No. 1s election was challenged by appellant, companyld number succeed. In regard to the second ground on which respondent No. 1s election was challenged by the appellant, the Tribunal held that Ext. 3 had been published by the agent of respondent No. 1 but number with his express companysent

facts.text: Election Tribunal not satisfied Ext. 6 published by respondent No. 1's agent.

anchor.surface_text: and in regard to Ext. 6, the Tribunal was number satisfied that, it had been published by respondent No. 1s agent.

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: That is how even the second ground made by the appellant disputing the validity of respondent No. 1s election did number succeed. In the result, the election petition was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the said decision, the appellant preferred an appeal in the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: High Court confirmed Tribunal's finding on invalid votes.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyfirmed the finding of the Tribunal on the first point in regard to the receipt of invalid votes.

facts.text: High Court accepted Tribunal's finding on publication of Ext. 3 by agent of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the second companytention raised by the appellant, the High Court has accepted the finding of the Tribunal about the publication of Ext. 3.

facts.text: High Court reversed Tribunal on Ext. 6, held published for benefit of respondent No. 1 with consent.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the other document Ext. 6, the High Court has reversed the companyclusion of the Tribunal and hold that the said document had been published for the benefit of respondent No. 1 and differing from the view taken by the Tribunal, the High Court has hold that the Publication of both the pamphlets was with companysent of respondent No. 1

facts.text: High Court held allegations in pamphlets false and prejudicial to respondent No. 2's prospects.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus found that the two pamphlets had been published by the agent of respondent No.1 and with his companysent, the High Court preceded to examine the question as to whether the material allegations made against respondent No. 2 by the said pamphlets were true or false. The High Court bold that the said material allegations were false and it came to the- companyclusion that they were calculated to effect prejudicially the prospects of the election of respondent No.2.

facts.text: High Court held statements did not relate to personal character or conduct of respondent No. 2, no corrupt practice under s.123(4).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was however, number satisfied that the said allegations had relation to the personal character or companyduct of respondent No. 2 and so it held that the companyrupt practice alleged by the appellant against respondent No. 2 on the strength of the said two pamphlets under s. 123 4  of the act had number been proved.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appellant's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that though the High Court differed from the Election Tribunal in regard to some of the findings recorded by the Tribunal on the second ground, its ultimate companyclusion was the same as that of the Tribunal. The appeal preferred by the appellant was accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court by Special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court held allegation in pamphlet that respondent No. 2 is purchaser of Congress opponents by money constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(4), affects personal character.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we are satisfied that the allegation made in the pamphlet that respondent No. 2 is a purchaser of the opponents of the Congress by means of money clearly attracts the provisions of ss. 123 4 .

facts.text: Supreme Court reversed High Court, declared election of respondent No. 1 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we must reverse the finding of the High Court that publication of the impugned pamphlets does number companystitute a companyrupt practice under as. 123 4 . The result of this companyclusion inevitably is that the election of respondent No. 1 must be declared to be invalid

facts.text: Supreme Court did not declare respondent No. 2 elected, as election in 1957 and fresh elections imminent in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The election which is challenged took place in 1957 and in fact we are number on the verge of fresh elections which would take place this month That is why we think it would serve numberpurpose in sending the matter back

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside election of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.

arguments.claim: Describing respondent No. 2 as agent of foreigners, supporter/collaborator of Pakistani conspiracy, purchaser of Congress opponents by money attacks personal character; constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(4)

The same companyment is made in respect of the description of respondent No. 2 as the supporter and companylaborator of the companyspiracy of Pakistani attack on Bharat ... anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, for respondent No. 1 Mr. Mathur who appeared amicus curaie at our request has companytended that the three allegations, though false, cannot be said to touch or effect the private character of respondent No. 2. He has argued that in dealing with s. 123  4 , it is necessary to make a distinction between the personal or private character or companyduct of a candidate and his public or political character.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: companye to make a gift of Kashmir to the aggressor Pakistan and had companye to enslave India by companylaborating with Pakistan and Pakistans friend

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction valid but borderline cases like bribery affect private character due to moral turpitude; not mere political criticism

arguments.claim: s.123(4) distinguishes personal/private character (protected) from public/political (open to criticism); legislative intent to allow fearless political debate while protecting against false personal attacks

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, necessary to determine the true scope and effect of the relevant provision in a. 123  4 . Section 123 deals with companyrupt practices ... The provision postulates that if a false statement is made in regard to the public or political character of the candidate, it would number companystitute a companyrupt practice ... That is why it is for the protection of the companystituency against acts which would be fatal to the freedom of election that the statute provides ...

arguments.claim: Purchaser by money allegation clearly attracts s.123(4) as bribery involves moral turpitude affecting private character

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we are satisfied that the allegation made in the pamphlet that respondent No. 2 is a purchaser of the opponents of the Congress by means of money clearly attracts the provisions of ss. 123 4 . In plain terms, the statement amounts to an allegation that respondent No. 2 buys by offering bribes the votes of the opponents of the Congress.

arguments.claim: High Court erred by not considering specific statements like bribery allegation; general reading as attack on class incorrect

It has dealt with this problem in very general terms. ... holdings.text: The question as to whether respondent No. 1â€™s election has been materially assisted by the receipt of invalid votes is concluded by concurrent finding of fact recorded against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether respondent No. 1s election has been materially assisted by the receipt of invalid votes, is concluded by concurrent finding of fact recorded against the appellant and so we have not allowed Mr. Sastri to dispute the correctness of that finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court defers to concurrent findings of Election Tribunal and Rajasthan High Court on factual issue of invalid votes.

holdings.text: The allegation that respondent No. 2 is a purchaser of the opponents of the Congress by means of money clearly attracts the provisions of s.123(4) as it relates to personal character involving moral turpitude.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we are satisfied that the allegation made in the pamphlet that respondent No. 2 is a purchaser of the opponents of the Congress by means of money clearly attracts the provisions of ss. 123 4 . In plain terms, the statement amounts to an allegation that respondent No. 2 buys by offering bribes the votes of the opponents of the Congress.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bribery allegation equates to offering bribes, introduces moral turpitude affecting private character beyond mere public/political criticism; High Court failed to consider specific statement.

holdings.text: False statements relating to public or political character of a candidate do not constitute corrupt practice under s.123(4); distinction exists between personal/private and public/political character.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, necessary to determine the true scope and effect of the relevant provision in s. 123(4). Section 123 deals with corrupt practices and amongst them, is the corrupt practice specified by subsection (4). That sub- section reads thus - The publication by a candidate or his agent or by any other person, of any statement of fact which is false...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative intent to protect fearless political debate on public character while prohibiting false personal attacks; borderline cases assessed by moral turpitude.

holdings.text: Publication of the impugned pamphlets constitutes a corrupt practice under s.123(4); reverses finding of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we must reverse the finding of the High Court that publication of the impugned pamphlets does not constitute a corrupt practice under s.123(4). The result of this conclusion inevitably is that the election of respondent No. 1 must be declared to be invalid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pamphlets published with consent by agent; contain false statements on personal character prejudicial to prospects; falls under s.100(1)(b), outside s.100(2).

holdings.text: The election of respondent No. 1 is declared invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The result of this conclusion inevitably is that the election of respondent No. 1 must be declared to be invalid because there is no doubt that the corrupt practice proved in this case falls under section 100(1)(b) and is outside the purview of section 100(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corrupt practice under s.123(4) with consent voids election per s.100(1)(b).

holdings.text: Respondent No. 2 shall not be declared duly elected under s.101(b); no remand to High Court.

This question will have to be decided in the light of provisions of section 101(b) of the Act... We do not, however, propose to adopt such a course in view of the fact that it would be futile...

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1957 election stale; fresh elections imminent in 1962; futile to remand for factual determination.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; election of respondent No. 1 declared invalid and set aside; no declaration that respondent No. 2 duly elected as question not considered due to futility given elapsed time and impending fresh elections

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether respondent No. 1s election has been materially assisted by the receipt of invalid votes, is concluded by concurrent finding of fact recorded against the appellant and so we have not allowed Mr. Sastri to dispute the correctness of that finding.
The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.

In the present case, we are satisfied that the allegation made in the pamphlet that respondent No. 2 is a purchaser of the opponents of the Congress by means of money clearly attracts the provisions of ss. 123 4 . In plain terms, the statement amounts to an allegation that respondent No. 2 buys by offering bribes the votes of the opponents of the Congress.
The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.

It is, therefore, necessary to determine the true scope and effect of the relevant provision in s. 123(4). Section 123 deals with corrupt practices and amongst them, is the corrupt practice specified by subsection (4). That sub- section reads thus - The publication by a candidate or his agent or by any other person, of any statement of fact which is false...
The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.

In the result we must reverse the finding of the High Court that publication of the impugned pamphlets does not constitute a corrupt practice under s.123(4). The result of this conclusion inevitably is that the election of respondent No. 1 must be declared to be invalid
The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.
The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.

That takes us to the question as to whether respondent No. 2 can be declared to have been validly elected at the election in question. This question will have to be decided in the light of provisions of section 101(b) of the Act... We do not, however, propose to adopt such a course in view of the fact that it would be futile...
The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.
The result is, the appeal is allowed and the election of respondent No. 1 is get aside.
